comments.commentBody:
You are asking the right question when you note that the cost of college tuition has far exceeded people's ability to pay, but you don't follow it to its logical conclusion.

Since 1965, college tuition has risen every year, sometimes at double the rate of general inflation. When I was in high school the minimum wage was $1.15 and full year tuition at an excellent private university cost $2350 - the ratio was about 2000 times. At today's minimum wage of about $8, that would equate to private college tuition of $16,000. Good luck with finding that. In fact tuition is about 48,000 or 4 times that amount. In contrast a nice Cadillac 4 door sedan in 1965 cost $5666 or 5000 times the minimum wage. At todays minimum wage, a Cadillac sedan should cost $40,000 and in fact costs about $36,000.

The truth is that University tuition is a bubble supported by scholarships and loans. The student loan market has just hit 1 trillion dollars, most of it government (taxpayer) guaranteed. This is similar to the Fannie Mae home loan situation that existed before the crash. The availability of this huge pot of money is what enables colleges to raise their tuition without any market constraint. Whenever they raise tuition, politicians step in to "help" students, when in fact it is this interference which enabled the tuition increase in the first place.

Tracing the difference in tuition costs isn't just a linear equation. There have been cultural changes that would have been scoffed at in the 1970s. For example, today your University of Washington football coach is the highest paid state employee, pulling in $1.98 million per year. No doubt football also makes money for the university, but it demonstrates that one can't just trace the cost of tuition vs. say, the price of eggs in 1971, and be outraged.

A 2002 Census Bureau study estimated that in 1999, the average lifetime earnings of a Bachelor’s degree holder was $2.7 million (2009 dollars), 75 percent more than that earned by high school graduates in 1999.

College loans are obviously way too expensive and corrupted by private banks' interest rates and state budget slashing Republicans on public education funding, which has led to the $1 trillion in college loans floating around as a bubble. These are serious problems that need addressing.

But still, even now, college - despite its enormous (almost crippling) initial cost - still offers significantly more long-term value than the alternative: a high school diploma. Taking on $40-50k in debt sounds like a lot (and no doubt it is), but when you compare to how much you'd make over a lifetime, it's a no-brainer investment.

"Israa Yassin, 18, from the village of Qab Elias, who is studying computer science, told me: “This whole program is helping to make the youth capable of transforming this country into what it should be and can be. We are good, and we have the capabilities and we can do a lot, but we don’t get the chance. My brother just finished high school, and he could not afford [university]. His future is really stopped."

I completely agree with the idea that helping to enrich lives brings more harmony and much better prospects for those in the Arab world, and much more good will. How ironic that some Republicans are apparently in love with war for the supposed toughness it shows and personal or corporate enrichment.

Meanwhile students right here in America are often unable to afford a public education at the college level. In the 1970s, I attended the University of Washington for about $70 a quarter, where today it costs thousands. The level of instruction was excellent, I felt challenged and knew I needed to do my best work in order to get a commensurate grade. Some have argued that college education costs so much in the U.S. now because we need to pay high prices to get the best teachers. Yet that logic did not seem to apply when I went to the university, where I experienced first class professors and courses. At the same time, the amount for military and defense spending has approximately doubled in ten years time. A huge disconnect.

To SCSOCAL- you've been watching too much fox propaganda.Clinton was called "obsessed with Bin-Laden" when he was in office,and the republicans said it was only to detract us from the REAL issues,like Monica.He was found not guilty on impeachment-with republicans voting.The impeachment was what was political,not the outcome.Get your facts straight.

That is American EXCEPTIONALISM  in deed rather that simply mouthing a hollow slogan.

Everytime the Dems get in they reduce our miltiary and then when we need them they are not there and we suffer losses.
Do you see other nations reducing their forces? Not hardly!

I always wonder what did happen in the period between WWII and the Korean War.   Somehow American lives lost value.  In WWII we would do anything to defeat an enemy, proecting American lives in the process, aka using the Atomic Bomb.  After that, we started to be more concerned with diplomacy resulting in caring for an enemy equal to the care we afford our own soldiers.  What has happened in these United States?

Where's Mitt? Eat your heart out. President Obama being president and presidential blow you out of the news cycle. It was a totally coup by the President. Great job and God speed to you Mr. President. I pray for you continued safety as well as the safety your family. You continue to make me proud to be an American.

Brilliant strategic move.

More war and conflict anyone?

Yes, I know! Must...choose...the...lesser...of...two...evils..... Even as more and more it all looks increasingly familiar. The opposite sides of the same coin. No fresh ideas, no real leadership to be found in sight.

Brian,

If Afghanistan was not landlocked, the president could have landed on an aircraft carrier in a flight suit and declared "mission accomplished."

It's silly season in Washington, DC because it works and both parties take advantage of it. But the incumbent has bigger campaign toys.

If it had been a republican that caught him,they would've reminded us weekly,and named him King.Instead,they claimed "not to care where he is".Or,as Mitt said."not worth the money to find him". But posing with Guliani in NYC is close enough,I guess.
Also,you must've forgotten the endless 9/11 talk from the republicans from 9/11 thru President Obama's win.
Sour grapes is all.He's proven,over and over,that he has what it takes.The republicans put us in danger with their ways,Obama's made us safer.Doesn't sit well with republicans PERCEIVED strengths,so they slam him.Luckily,most of us aren't that gullible.

'What a waste of time, money and aviation fuel'.  Yep, just like former President GWB's "grand standing" in a flight suit in 2003 on a aircraft carrier bragging about "Mission Accomplished".  Yes, a REAL waste indeed!
Lets hope Karzai will be up to the challenge but I am far from optimistic about that issue.  For all of us, time to pack up our gears and go home.
Tens of thousands in the streets of NYC and nothing on the homepage N Y Times? Really? NY? Really?
Viet Nam all over again, except much worse for the US this time. Because we are broke, and can't afford this in any way. Disaster for the US.

"The great unwashed" ... love it!

As someone currently planning a return to India, I couldn't have described it better ... and one would miss it if they didn't dwell individually on 'great' and 'unwashed'. Thanks for making me LOL ... and befriend your non-friend again, if only because such a wit is not easy to find these days.

As Shashi Tharoor also described it (in a more verbose fashion), India is 'a highly developed (nation) in an advanced state of decay'. You see it ... given time, your friend will as well.

It is so very easy to sit on a comfortable chair (perhaps sip a good coffee as well) and comment on the tribulations in the world. It is FAR more difficult to actually implement meaningful and sustainable changes.

What this reader would suggest to people like Lorenzo of New York is to do something meaningful. Rather than making impersonal and caustic comments, join a NGO and participate in a positive change - or at the least make a contribution. Perhaps then from personal experience one should make realistic comments.

Besides, to whose God are you referring - if you quote "..go forth and multiply"? Taken from Bible I assume. However, though there is a very large Christian population in India, that is NOT the motto most other Indians - including Christians - follow. Please do educate yourself about India - it is a far more complex country than ANY in the world, with all its flaws (is there a country without one?).

Blame should be placed where it belongs
On GW Bush and Dick and Rumsfeld and wolfowitz. they wanted war and invented reasons(LIES) to push us into war
Anyone who disagreed was styled a traitor or un American.
I watched in astonishment as we went to war in a place anyone who reads history would know is a loser no winner place.
Obama or any president could not just pull out
As much as I wish he could.
2014 isn't fast enough but remember
If up to the Repubs
We would stay forever in Afghanistan, Iraq and start a new war in Iran.
As long as their kids don't have to fight.
Next war someone starts we should reinstate the draft
If war
War for all.

It's about time.  LIke some Americans after 9/11, I opposed the 'eye for an eye' invasion of Afghanistan, preferring instead to work through diplomatic channels that were alleged to be open with the Taliban.  Al Queda was not an official Afghani organization, and the Taliban might have been willing to give them up were it not for the cowboy mentality of our last president.  Fast forward eleven years and countless lives, and, lo and behold, we are *not* at war with the Taliban, but rather with Al Queda.  Seems to me the war was a huge waste of lives and treasure. The raid on Osama bin Laden in Pakistan, or something like it, could have been accomplished with "actionable intelligence" that did not involve an eleven year occupation.  There was certainly a lot more good will towards the American cause before the invasion, and that could have been used to much greater advantage if our leaders had shown less eagerness to use bunker-buster bombs all over Afghanistan.  I'd like to give Nobel-prize-winning Barack Obama credit for finally seeing the light, but really, this is too little too late.

Why did the President pledge to extricate the US from this war? Because everytime America steps into "it" they leave a mess behind. A decade ago "W" was doing his song and dance vaudelville routine onborard an aircraft carrier...a farce with another decade of bloodshed to follow it. This time, pull the forces out, but clean up your mess. Afganistan can never be "won"....it has not for over 2,000 years. Bush did not learn the hard lessons of the Soviet Union in the day. It is unconscienable to invade a country, and even more unconscienable to cause even more complexity. This was the wise decision to stop the blood of Americans left in that wasteland....and us Canadians may I remind you ...Bravo Mr. President. Some commentators still draw lines along religion...have we learned nothing since the crusades? Today's announcement is good news for the military families in both our countries. Be thankful they will be united with their children, wives and parents.

Why does a president who pledged to extricate the US from endless, blood-and-treasure draining wars in Islamic countries where our presence is increasingly resented insist on staying in bed for a decade or more with the corrupt regime which holds power there are frequently trashes its "benefactor?" It's a crazy policy and today's announcement is not good news.

"How much money must we give to a corrupt and imagined state?"

Well, in the world of empire, there are only two solutions: (1) you pay them off and then you own them or (2) you invade, occupy them and then you own them. Which one is the best option now that we know that #2 hasn't worked all that well? Of course, a reasonable man would argue that we can't stop all the imperialism and go back to concentrating on the republic but that's out of the realm of possibilities, particularly to the Fascist right wing regime we're already under.

How much money must we give to a corrupt and imagined state? Mr. Karzai is beyond corrupt, for he is one of the most lawless characters I've ever seen. Mr. Obama could have done much better by abandoning the whole of Afghanistan and the poppy for which they are so keen on producing. The troops should be removed without further delay. All spending must cease forthwith. Before my demise, Islamist will govern Afghanistan. Democracy does not fit and it is not desired in Afghanistan. History has demonstrated this fact repeatedly. Profiteering must cease. Destroying lives, of both Americans and others, must stop immediately. JUST GET OUTOF THAT PLACE NOW.

One should always suggest the rationale behind a sweeping comment in a short and single sentence!!

India is NOT Mexico. Due to its size, traditions, history, cultural diversity (in religion, language, ethnicity, etc.), geography, etc. NO country can be compared with India - certainly not easily.

The history of Indian civilization goes back four-five thousands years. Unlike most other older countries - even China - there has been a very strong continuity of ancient Indian culture (with its trials and tribulations of course).

Four major religions (Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism and Sikhism) originated in India. No other country except Saudi Arabia (for Islam), Israel (Judaism) and Palestine (Christianity) can even claim to be the origin of a major religion. In addition it has the second or third largest (depending on who is counting) Muslim population in the world. It has a sizable population of Christians and a host of other minor religions.

It has fourteen major official languages (with 10 million or more speakers), other minor ones and depending on who is counting, hundreds of dialects.

Its climate varies from tropical to sub-tropical, temperate, cold and dry (as in the articles here).

It has a myriad of cultures and sub-cultures - including in some literally stone-age tribes in remote ares of certain islands.

One can go on and on.

Please - educate yourself. Then find the rationale and chances are that you'll find how wrong you are.
How about teaching these people how to swim?
Great story, thank you!
Good comment except that you have it backward;  Time to get out with our money and most importantly, our men and women.

What nonsense. There's no partnership with Hamid Karzai or Afghanistan.

We can't trust them and they hate everyone, including their own people.

Time to get out with our men, women and most important our money. Good luck Afghanistan!
The President of Raagapella is very pompous for being head of a group on the downhill.

A BRICS infrastructure development bank would serve the valuable function of advancing economic and social development in the BRICS and other developing countries. Transportation networks and other infrastructure are vital to maintaining economic growth and extending the benefits of economic development to more areas and people. To keep pace with development and rapid urbanization, every day growing cities in developing countries across Asia need to add a total of 20,000 new dwellings, 250km of new roads and infrastructure to deliver 6 million more liters of potable water, according to calculations by the Asian Development Bank. So far, China’s growth alone has lifted more half a billion people out of poverty. Development banks (e.g., Asian Development Bank, African Development Bank, Inter-American Development Bank) play an important role by providing patient, long-term capital for infrastructure investments that are otherwise far too vulnerable to market failures and the short-term mindset of the financial markets. This kind of investment should be welcomed, and a BRICS bank could add substantially to the beneficial work that others are doing around the world. (Source: http://www.globalsherpa.org/bric-countries-brics )

Obama buys lunch for over 46 million with food stamps, due to lack of economic prosperity.  Could be a bad day for Democrats come November.

Today was a really bad day for Republicans.
